Articles.Content:
Stock is definitely easier in most respects, I'll say that. But yeah, with a properly area-ruled craft in FAR you might barely even notice the sound barrier, whereas in stock you basically just have to try and ram everything through it.

In my head that's always been the trade off; stock will let you fly pretty much any old crock, and land it without hassle. FAR makes you work hard to get a good design together, but ultimately has the potential to get you to orbit with significantly better efficiency. 1.0.4 vs the last release of FAR were, however, almost identical. I was getting the same plane to orbit in both, with less than 10% difference in remaining fuel, so I was having a hard time justifying the extra time in the SPH ^^;

Kerbodyne Swagman.

Craft file at https://www.dropbox.com/s/ulctvafknwl9ilw/Kerbodyne%20Swagman.craft?dl=0

One Mk2 low-tech medium tanker, ready to go:

Reminds me of the Cacafuego. Still have that ship, served me well. +Rep.

Stock is definitely easier in most respects, I'll say that. But yeah, with a properly area-ruled craft in FAR you might barely even notice the sound barrier, whereas in stock you basically just have to try and ram everything through it.

K, that was interesting. My

for once turned out significantly higher numbers under the new dev build; 1425m/s on air and went from 360-440 delta-v in LKO up to 660. Used to have 2.8 wave drag, now it has 1.4.

Need to do more experiments to see whether that translates to other sizes... but up to 50% more fuel in orbit is a powerful lure.

I love the look of that one, but it could do with a smaller intake, it wont need as much air because it wont go as high.

Previously, I would have gone with a pointy cockpit and smaller intake. But with the new intake flow-through drag reduction...

Lander and a lab to pretty much anywhere and back isn't bad But I feel like a long MK3 could do the same job, given an in-orbit refuel

Really need to invest in aerodynamic parts in my latest career, but it's hard to justify vs unlocking more science instruments and scanners to put on long range probes... x(

Nice, not seen anyone do a RATO yet. I like the lander-in-the-trunk approach too

To be honest, that one could probably manage without the RATO. But it is a handy trick for bigger things, and easier than you'd think.

Monoprop landers are heavy, but very compact. They're a good choice for weight-tolerant but space-limited applications like this.

That whole aircraft gives me a case of the WHYs

That whole aircraft gives me a case of the WHYs

1) Because it was there.

2) How else are you going to get ~9,000m/s ÃŽâ€V and tolerable TWR out of a crewed reentry-capable craft not much bigger than an F-16?

But, yeah, there isn't a whole lot of practical application for it in standard career KSP. All the complexity of an SSTO minus the financial efficiency. Disposable rockets are cheaper than disposable jets.

~9,000m/s ÃŽâ€V and tolerable TWR out of a crewed reentry-capable craft not much bigger than an F-16

That's... Actually a surprisingly good idea.

Like crazy genius kind of good

That's... Actually a surprisingly good idea.

Like crazy genius kind of good

Unfortunately, while it has the size of a fighter jet, it also has the cost of a fighter jet. Big dumb rockets are cheaper by a hefty margin.

Unfortunately, while it has the size of a fighter jet, it also has the cost of a fighter jet. Big dumb rockets are cheaper by a hefty margin.

Question, how effective is money as a reaction mass?

Question, how effective is money as a reaction mass?

Depends on the current exchange rate.

Is there any point in using the shock cone intake anymore? from what I can tell, it has less intake area, less intake capacity, and pretty much the same drag.

Is there any point in using the shock cone intake anymore? from what I can tell, it has less intake area, less intake capacity, and pretty much the same drag.

Better heat performance, last I knew
